questions.question:
Question 1: A mother observed unusual redness on the palms of her young child while putting him to 
sleep. She brings him to your OPD and on examination, you find mild abdominal distension, 
splenomegaly, and pedal edema. You admit the child for further evaluation, but on the night 
of admission, he suddenly starts vomiting fresh blood. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
A child presenting with hematemesis and splenomegaly is presumed to have variceal bleeding 
unless proved otherwise. Bleeding from oesophagal varices is the most common presentation of 
portal hypertension. Palmar erythema(redness of the palms) and ascites (swelling of the abdomen) are features of liver 
failure seen in this patient. Upper GI endoscopy is the preferred diagnostic test for oesophagal varices. The management of acute variceal bleeding- • Attain hemodynamic stability through blood transfusion/fluids • Vasoactive drugs (e.g., octreotide) • Endoscopy to perform ligation or sclerotherapy • Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt should be considered for variceal bleeding 
refractory to medical and endoscopic therapy. Secondary prophylaxis to reduce the recurrence of bleeding includes- • Nonselective  blockade (propranolol, nadolol) • Obliteration of varices through serial treatment via ligation or sclerotherapy 391 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 2: A 10-year-old boy was brought by his mother to the ER after having a sudden episode of 
vomiting blood. On examination, splenomegaly is detected with engorged superficial veins 
around his umbilicus. Which is the investigation of choice in this patient?
questions.explanation:
A child presenting with hematemesis and splenomegaly is presumed to have variceal bleeding and 
hence, upper GI endoscopy is the investigation of choice. The upper GI endoscopy provides a definitive diagnosis and an option to treat via band ligation or 
sclerotherapy. Capsule endoscopy, ultrasound, CT, MRI, and elastography are not recommended because of their 
suboptimal accuracy compared to endoscopy. Capsule endoscopy is used to investigate an 
occult/obscure gastrointestinal bleed mostly suspected to be in the small intestine.

questions.question:
Question 3: Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, which did not subside even after 3 weeks of birth, was 
observed in a neonate. On investigating, liver enzymes, PT/INR and albumin levels were 
normal. No hemolysis was seen on a peripheral blood smear. A drop in bilirubin level was 
observed within a week after treating with phenobarbital. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Jaundice persisiting 3 weeks after birth is suggestive of pathological jaundice. Among the given 
options, Crigler Najjar type 2 presents with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia which responds 
to phenobarbital therapy. Dubin Johnson (option C) and Rotor (option A) syndromes lead to conjugated 
hyperbilirubinemia. Crigler Najjar type 2 is an autosomal recessive disease with non-hemolytic, unconjugated 
hyperbilirubinemia caused by homozygous missense mutations in the enzyme UDP 
UGT1A1 resulting in reduced (partial) enzymatic activity. The differences between Crigler-Najjar type 1 and type 2 are described in the table below: Crigler Najjar Type 1

Question 4: A 14-year-old boy was brought to the OPD by his father who observed a yellowish tinge to his 
skin and eyes. He gives a history of recent onset fatigue after playing football for a few 
minutes and cannot stay active on the playground for a long time like before. Investigations 
revealed isolated conjugated hyperbilirubinemia but are normal otherwise. Liver histology 
revealed a black pigment. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The presence of fatigue, conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and black pigment on liver biopsy, termed 
as "black liver" is suggestive of Dubin–Johnson syndrome. Dubin-Johnson syndrome is an autosomal recessive inherited defect in hepatocyte secretion of 
bilirubin glucuronide. Disease results from absent function of multiple drug-resistant protein 
2, an ATP dependent canalicular transporter. 392

Question 5: You are an intern posted in the paediatrics department and a child with Dubin-Johnson 
syndrome is admitted to your unit. During rounds, the attending paediatrician asks you 
which molecular defect causes liver disease in this patient. Your answer would be
questions.explanation:
Molecular defect causing liver disease in Dubin–Johnson syndrome is ABCC2 (codes for 
canalicular protein with ATP-binding cassette), it leads to the mutation of multiple drug-resistant 
protein 2 (MRP2) receptor. Hence, there is a defect in the transfer of conjugated bilirubin from 
the liver to bile in Dubin–Johnson syndrome. Important diseases and their molecular defects: ATP7A

questions.question: Question 6: All are true about transient familial neonatal hyperbilirubinemia, except:

options.b: Occurs due to maternal antibody against fetal UGT1A1
options.c: It is also known as Lucey Driscoll syndrome
options.d: Stop breast feeding when jaundice sets in

questions.explanation:
Lucey Driscoll syndrome or transient familial neonatal hyperbilirubinemia is a self-limiting 
condition and there is no need to stop breastfeeding. Lucey Driscoll syndrome is an autosomal recessive metabolic disorder affecting enzymes involved 
in bilirubin metabolism. It causes transient familial neonatal unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia 
and jaundice occurs during the first 4 days of life. It is due to maternal antibodies against fetal 
UGT1A1 (UDP glucuronosyltransferase family 1 member A1). 393 
Sold by @itachibot

Question 7: Lately, a teacher observed that an anxious young girl had started drooling saliva from her 
mouth while listening in the classroom. She had also developed a deterioration in her 
handwriting while taking down notes. Her mother was informed and she brought her child to 385 
Sold by @itachibot your clinic. On examination, she had tremors and mild hepatomegaly. A slit-lamp 
examination was done and showed the following picture. The right statement about this 
disease is -

options.c: Coombs-positive hemolytic anaemia may be present.
options.d: Patient can be treated with triethylenetetramine

questions.explanation:
The image shows the Kayser-Fleischer ring, which is characteristic of Wilson's disease. It is an 
autosomal recessive disorder, characterised by low serum ceruloplasmin levels. Coomb's negative 
hemolytic anemia may be present. The patient can be treated with triethylenetetramine also 
known as trientine. Wilson’s disease is caused due to a loss-of-function mutation in the ATP7B gene on Chr.13q. The 
gene encodes a copper transporting ATPase (ATP7B) which has 2 functions: • Maintains copper in bound form by binding copper to apoceruloplasmin • Helps excrete free copper in bile. Thus, an ATP7B deficiency leads to excess deposition of free copper within tissues. The drugs used in the management of Wilson's disease include: • Chelating agents as first-line drugs • D-penicillamine • Trientine or triethylenetetramine • Elemental zinc as maintenance therapy. Question 8: A mother observed deterioration in her young child's academic performance and loss of 
interest in everyday activities for the last few weeks. She has also lost the ability to play catch 
with her brother and complains of muscle weakness. There is mild hepatomegaly noted on 
examination. Her serum ceruloplasmin levels were reduced. All of the following 
manifestations can occur in a patient with this disease except?
questions.explanation:
The presence of reduced ceruloplasmin levels, motor incoordination, and hepatomegaly suggest 
the patient is suffering from Wilson’s disease. Sparse depigmented hair is not a feature of Wilson's 
disease. It is a feature of Menke's disease. Wilson's disease is caused due to a mutation in the ATP7B gene that leads to excess deposition of 
free copper within tissues. It has the following clinical features: Note: Wilson's disease may also present as cirrhosis and hepatic failure, where shrinkage of liver 
occurs. 394

questions.explanation:
In Wilson disease, hepatic copper content usually exceeds 250 g/g dry weight. Hepatic copper accumulation is the hallmark of Wilson disease. It is measured using neutron 
activation analysis/atomic absorption spectrometry.

questions.question:
Question 10: A male infant was born to a mother with chronic hepatitis B infection. The infant is suspected 
to have been exposed at the time of delivery. At 4 months, which of the following viral 
markers signifies ongoing viral replication in the infant?
questions.explanation: HBeAg signifies the ongoing viral replication in case of hepatitis B infection.

questions.question:
Question 11: A 9-year-old boy was brought to the OPD by his mother with a history of fatigue and myalgia 
for a few days, associated with rashes that started a week before it. On examination, 
coppery-red coloured skin lesions were seen on the face and limbs including palms and soles. 
His serology was positive for HBsAg. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The coppery-red colored papules along with a positive HBsAg are suggestive of Gianotti-Crosti 
syndrome, also known as papular acrodermatitis. It is an immunologic reaction to viral infections. The most common associations are Epstein-Barr 
virus, hepatitis B virus, Coxsackievirus A16, and parainfluenza virus, as well as with many 
childhood immunizations. Skin lesions are monomorphic, firm, coppery red papules sized 1-10 mm. They occur in crops and 
may become profuse and coalesce into plaques, forming a symmetric eruption on the face, ears, 
buttocks, and limbs, including the palms and soles. The trunk, scalp, and mucous membrane are 
relatively spared. The image given below shows the coppery red papules seen in Gianotti-Crosti syndrome. 395 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following drugs are not used in the treatment of hepatitis B?
questions.explanation: Ribavirin is a drug used in the treatment of hepatitis C, not hepatitis B. Indications for starting antiviral therapy in chronic hepatitis B are: • Patients without cirrhosis • HBeAg + with HBV DNA >20,000 IU/mL and ALT level >2 times the upper limit of normal • HBeAg -ve with HBV DNA >2000 IU/mL and ALT level >2 times the upper limit of normal • Patients with compensated cirrhosis and an HBV DNA >2000 IU/mL • Patients developing acute liver failure or decompensated cirrhosis. Drugs used in the treatment of hepatitis B are: • First-line treatment: Entecavir or tenofovir • Other drugs: • Pegylated interferon-alpha • Telbivudine • Lamivudine • Adefovir

questions.question:
Question 13: A young child developed sudden bouts of vomiting and was brought to the ER. Her condition 
rapidly worsened as she developed seizures. She had a history of influenza infection one week 
ago. The patient's liver biopsy will show  
.
questions.explanation:
Severe vomiting in a 5-year-old child, rapidly worsening to seizures, with a history of viral 
infection (influenza) is suggestive of Reye's syndrome. Hence, liver biopsy will show marked 
microvesicular steatosis. 396 
Sold by @itachibot Reye's syndrome is a secondary mitochondrial hepatopathy. It is precipitated due to • Viral infection (influenza, adenovirus, herpes, coxsackievirus A, Epstein–Barr virus) • Salicylate or antiemetic use • Inborn error of metabolism such as single enzyme defects of ß oxidation. • Toxins There is an acute onset of vomiting and encephalopathy, rapidly progressing to seizures, 
coma, and death. There is no jaundice. Investigations •  ALT and AST •  Ammonia • normal bilirubin • Hypoglycemia • PT prolonged • INR increased • Liver biopsy: marked microvesicular steatosis. Necrosis is not seen.

questions.question:
Question 14: A 12-year old girl was rushed to the ER by her parents due to hematemesis. They gave a 
history of weakness and fatigue for the last few weeks. On examination, the patient had 
spider telangiectasias and mild palmar erythema. Liver function tests showed the following 
results- AST-1100IU/L, serum bilirubin- 8mg/dl, albumin- decreased, globulin- elevated, PT- 
prolonged along with Anti-Nuclear Antibody positive. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The symptoms of liver failure and portal hypertension along with a positive anti-nuclear 
antibody(ANA) is suggestive of Type 1 autoimmune hepatitis. It is associated with- • Elevated serum aminotransaminase concentrations. • Liver-associated serum autoantibodies. • Hypergammaglobulinemia.

Question 15: A 2-week-old low-birth-weight neonate presents with jaundice. Stools are pale/clay coloured. 
Liver biopsy shows loss of architecture. The most likely diagnosis is 
.
questions.explanation:
Neonatal jaundice in a low-birth-weight (LBW) neonate with consistently pale/clay coloured stools 
with liver biopsy finding of loss of architecture is suggestive of neonatal hepatitis. Wilson disease and hereditary hemochromatosis will not present with jaundice in the neonatal 
stage. Hence, they can be excluded. Injury to liver cells can present the clinical and histologic 
picture of “neonatal hepatitis.” Differentiation between Neonatal hepatitis and EHBA 397

Question 16: A mother is concerned about her 3-week-old baby having yellowish discolouration of skin and 
eyes. On examination, the baby is chubby and playful. Stools are pale in color. Further 388 
Sold by @itachibot evaluation with USG shows triangular cord sign and liver biopsy shows bile duct 
proliferation. The most likely diagnosis is  
.
questions.explanation:
Neonatal jaundice in a neonate without a sick-looking appearance and with acholic stools, USG 
showing triangular cord sign, and liver biopsy showing bile duct proliferation is suggestive of 
biliary obstruction, which may be seen in biliary atresia. Wilson disease and Hallervorden Spatz disease (neurodegeneration with iron accumulation in the 
brain) do not present with jaundice in the neonatal stage. Hence, they can be excluded. Differentiation between neonatal hepatitis and EHBA Liver biospy: • Biliary atresia is characterized by proliferation of the bile ductule, presence of bile plugs, and 
portal or perilobular edema and fibrosis, with the basic hepatic lobular architecture intact. • In neonatal hepatitis, there is severe, diffuse hepatocellular disease, with distortion of lobular 
architecture, marked infiltration of inflammatory cells, and focal hepatocellular necrosis. Neonatal hepatitis

Question 17: A mother leaves her 3-year-old son unattended for 20 mins and later finds him holding a blue 
coloured empty strip of tablets with a few tablets scattered on the floor. A few hours later he 
is rushed to the ER with nausea and vomiting. As an intern taking the history, you suspect 
accidental ingestion of paracetamol tablets. The pattern of liver injury you would expect in 
this case is
questions.explanation:
The pattern of liver injury caused by paracetamol (acetaminophen) is centrilobular necrosis. Acetaminophen toxicity results from the formation of a highly reactive intermediate metabolite, N 
-acetyl-p -benzoquinone imine (NAPQI). In therapeutic use, only about 5% is metabolized by the 
hepatic cytochrome P450 enzyme CYP2E1 to NAPQI, which is then immediately joined with 
glutathione to form a nontoxic mercapturic acid conjugate. In overdose, glutathione stores are overwhelmed, and free NAPQI is able to combine with hepatic 
macromolecules to produce hepatocellular necrosis. Single acute toxic dose of APAP is generally 
considered to be >200 mg/kg in children. Patterns of hepatic drug injury: Disease

Question 18: You are examining a young child who presented to the ER with a high fever and abdominal 
pain. The patient winces on abdominal palpation of the right upper quadrant. USG showed 
hydrops of the gallbladder. All of the following conditions are associated with hydrops of the 
gallbladder except  
.
questions.explanation:
Hydrops of the gallbladder is not associated with cystic fibrosis. Hydrops of gallbladder is the acute acalculous non-inflammatory distension of the gallbladder, 
which occurs in infants and children. It is characterized by the absence of calculi, bacterial 
infections or congenital anomalies of the biliary system. 399 
Sold by @itachibot Hydrops is distinguished from acalculous cholecystitis by the absence of a significant 
inflammatory process and a generally benign prognosis. Conditions associated with hydrops of GB: • Infections: Streptococcal pharyngitis, staphylococcal infection, ascariasis, leptospirosis, typhoid 
fever, and viral hepatitis • Kawasaki disease • Total parenteral nutrition, prolonged fasting • Sickle cell crisis, thalassemia • Sepsis • Mesenteric adenitis, necrotizing enterocolitis Note: In cystic fibrosis cholelithiasis, cholecystitis, micro gallbladder is seen.

questions.question: Question 19: The commonest indication for liver transplantation in children is
questions.explanation:
Biliary atresia is the most common indication for liver transplantation in children. Extrahepatic biliary atresia (EHBA) is defined as a partial or total absence of permeable bile duct 
between the porta hepatis and the duodenum. It is due to inflammatory fibrosis of the biliary 
tree. It leads to obstruction to bile flow thereby causing the leaking of conjugated bilirubin into 
the circulation. Infants have symptoms of jaundice, pale stools, and dark urine right after birth. In advanced 
disease, infants present with failure to thrive, hepatomegaly, and ascites due to liver cirrhosis. HIDA scan is the investigation of choice for extrahepatic biliary atresia. An intraoperative 
cholangiogram is a gold standard investigation for diagnosis. Children with biliary atresia, who do not achieve successful drainage after 
hepatoportoenterostomy (Kasai's procedure), require liver transplantation within the first year of 
life. Management of extrahepatic
